awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Web-based Application for the Treatment of Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a web-based application to help women manage Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS). PCOS is the most common endocrine disorder in women and leads to higher risk of obesity, heart disease, diabetes, infertility, and cancer. Women with PCOS are using on average 5 to 6 separate apps to manage their symptoms. Many of these apps are not based upon research. Women with PCOS note frustration, confusion and exhaustion trying to determine the right diet and the right way to manage their health problems. Many do not have access to a specialist or even a local health care provider with knowledge of PCOS. The goal is to educate women with PCOS about their unique nutritional and metabolic needs and to offer “one place” for women with PCOS to go for evidence-based advice from experts in this field.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a web-based application for the treatment of Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS).  Research has shown that PCOS patients may control and mitigate their symptoms by managing their diet. The unique feature of this diet is that it is not based on counting caloric intakes, rather it is based on eliminating certain elements from the diet. The technology is based on a prospective clinical trial leading to an average weight loss of 19 pounds in 8 weeks without counting calories, carbs or fats. In addition, participants showed a 50% reduction in fasting insulin and a significant reduction in total testosterone as well. The goals of the proposed technology are to provide evidence-based education about PCOS directly to patients, and to relieve some of the burden on health care providers who care for these patients.  The goal is to provide education and treatment based on 10 years of research conducted by nutritional and medical experts for the management of PCOS.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report

 

Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) affects 12% of reproductive age woman making it the most common endocrine disorder in young women. PCOS is diagnosed by having 2 of 3 criteria including irregular menstrual cycles, laboratory or clinical evidence of elevated male-type hormones and the presence of at least one polycystic appearing ovary. Other conditions that mimic PCOS must be ruled out such as thyroid disorders, adrenal disorders, elevated prolactin or an androgen secreting tumor. The variability of presentation and required laboratory and clinical criteria result in many women having a delayed or missed diagnosis. Likewise, there is no standard universally accepted treatment for PCOS leading to under treatment and frustration for women with PCOS and their health care providers alike. 

 

This NSF I-Corps award allowed a team of physicians and a dietitian to interview more than 100 women with PCOS as well as their health care providers (physicians, nurses, dietitians and counselors).  The team learned first hand what was working and not working in access to care, timely and accurate diagnosis, and mutual frustrations for women with PCOS and their health care providers. 

 

Taking this information to a team of software developers resulted in the formation of “Ovara” - a native application providing free education about PCOS and tools to manage it. Tools include educational videos, a nutritional guide, grocery list builder and recipes for PCOS friendly meals. 

 

The minimal viable product (MVP) launched in May 2022 and has hundreds of subscribers. Future endeavors are planned to explore telemedicine resources for women with PCOS living in rural locations or who have limited access to providers. 

 

Feedback from the public has been extremely positive. The NSF I-Corps award and mentoring enabled the project to be completed in the least expensive and most efficient way possible. 

 

 


Last Modified: 03/15/2023
Modified by: Jennifer Phy
